sections.title: The Power of Time
sections.content: Credit scoring models look at how long your accounts have been open, the average age of your accounts, and how long it has been since you used them. Closing older accounts can shorten your average age, so think before you cancel long-standing cards.

sections.title: Authorized User Boost
sections.content: If a trusted family member has a long, positive credit history, becoming an authorized user on their account can help you build history quickly. Make sure the issuer reports authorized user activity to the bureaus and that the account stays in good standing.

sections.title: Starting from Zero
sections.content: New to credit? Apply for a secured card or a credit-builder loan offered by credit unions and fintech apps. Make small purchases and pay them off in full each month. On-time payments will populate your report and start the clock on your history.

points.title: Keep Old Accounts Active
points.description: Use them for small recurring charges and pay them off to keep them reporting.

points.title: Season New Accounts
points.description: Avoid applying for multiple cards in a short window. Space applications 6-12 months apart.

points.title: Diversify Over Time
points.description: Mix credit types — card, installment loan, auto loan — when it aligns with your goals.

sections.title: Maintenance Habits
sections.content: Set payment reminders, automate minimums, and review statements monthly. Keep utilization low, dispute errors promptly, and build a small emergency fund to avoid missed payments during unexpected expenses.

sections.title: Pro Tip
sections.content: When you graduate from a secured card, keep it open if there is no annual fee. The long history continues to help your score even if you rarely use it.
